instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.S5_PWRGD: What is S5_PWRGD? The S5_PWRGD signal is a status signal that indicates the S5 rails are on and functioning properly. If this is not present, check the S5 rails to see if they are functioning, and the chip that creates S5_PWRGD..
definitions.PP1V05_S0:
What is PP1V05_S0? The PP1V05_S0 power rail is for various components on the logic board that require a 1.05V supply voltage in the S0 (on) state. This voltage rail is likely to be used by the CPU (for VCCIO), PCH (Platform Controller Hub).

.
definitions.PP1V8_S3: What is PP1V8_S3? The PP1V8_S3 signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides a voltage of 1.8 volts during the S3 power state. The S3 state, often referred to as "suspend to RAM," is a low-power mode where the computer saves the session's state to RAM, allowing for quicker wake-up times compared to a full shutdown..
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT: What is PP0V6_S0_DDRVTT? Power rail for RAM. .
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.SMC_DELAYED_PWRGD: What is SMC_DELAYED_PWRGD? SMC_DELAYED_PWRGD is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a pre-requisite for SYS_PWROK_R and PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK..
definitions.CPU_VR_EN: What is CPU_VR_EN? CPU_VR_EN is an enable signal for CPU VCORE that is present when it is high. Signals with EN on the end enable whatever came before the EN if the signal is high. Signals with EN on the end enable whatever came before the EN if the signal is high. ALL_SYS_PWRGD, PM_RSMRST_L, PM_SLP_SUS_L, and PM_SLP_S3_L are necessary prerequisites for CPU_VR_EN to be present. .

threads.title: 820-000165 - Missing <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Hi Guys, 

Basically i got most of the rails,  except the <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>.
Any hint from this point?

Here is some measurements:

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 8.6V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 3.3
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> - 5V
<SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> = 3.35V
<SIGNAL>SMC_S5_PWRGD_VIN</SIGNAL> = 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL> = 1.05V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S3</SIGNAL> = 1.7V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> = 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> = 3.32v
[B]<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> = 0v[/B]


Thank you

threads.title: 820-000165 - Missing <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Do you get <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>?
Didn't mention RAM voltage, if present.

threads.title: 820-000165 - Missing <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
VCORE voltage must be present, to get <SIGNAL>SYS_PWROK</SIGNAL>.
Post <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> voltages...

threads.title: 820-000165 - Missing <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<CHIP>U1950</CHIP>
Pin 1 = 3.3V
Pin 2 = 3.3V
Pin 3 = 3.38V

Pin 5-7 = 3.38V
Pin 6 - 3.38V
Pin 8 = 3.38V

threads.title: 820-000165 - Missing <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
If <SIGNAL>SMC_DELAYED_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is high, VCORE should be present too; check it again.
Also check <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PLT_RST_BUF_L</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: 820-000165 - Missing <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
That is the problem.
Check <CHIP>U1930</CHIP> area.

threads.title: 820-000165 - Missing <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Looks clean. However, i replaced and i got the same measurements:

<RESISTOR>R1931</RESISTOR> =
1 = 1.05V
2 = 0V

<CAPACITOR>C1930</CAPACITOR> =
1 = 3.3V




<CHIP>U1930</CHIP> =
Pin 1 = 3.3V
Pin 2 = 3.3V
Pin 6 = 3.3V
Pin 4 = 0V

threads.title: 820-000165 - Missing <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Post diode mode to ground at <SIGNAL>CPU_VCCST_PWRGD</SIGNAL>.
Check J1800 area for corrosion; remove <RESISTOR>R1800</RESISTOR>.
Change <CHIP>U1930</CHIP> again.

You can also try the board removing <CHIP>U1930</CHIP>.

CPU remains as the culprit in the end.

threads.title: 820-000165 - Missing <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>CPU_VCCST_PWRGD</SIGNAL> = DM = 0.724
J1800 Clean
R18000 Removed
<CHIP>U1930</CHIP> Replaced (twice)

threads.title: 820-000165 - Missing <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
"You can also try the board removing <CHIP>U1930</CHIP>."
???

threads.title: 820-000165 - Missing <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>CPU_VCCST_PWRGD</SIGNAL> still low and <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL> present?
Then is dead CPU...
